data.description: A magazine focused on experimental electronic music. It started in 1987 as magazine on paper. Its simple xeroxed form ensured people were encouraged to make copies and distribute them freely.
5 artefacts, varying from posters to drawings and images, focused on the tensions between the Eastern and Western fronts during the Cold War.
A collection of 114 stamps made during the eight year war between Iran and Iraq.

A poster for the Korean Cultural & Speaking Tour in Asia-Pacific Europe called ‘Sound of Liberation’. The event was revolving around the unification of Korea. It took place in Luxembourg, Belgium, Germany, the Netherlands, Ireland, France and the United Kingdom.
An orange flip (alarm) clock with the NVV union logo on it produced between 1950 and 1974. It's speculated it was given to the NVV members at the time as a gift.

Textile scarf, called Hero's Scarf by Mieke Gerritzen. The scraf is covered in a pattern of images of all modern icons and public figures, such as Mickey Mouse, Nelson Mandela, Marylin Monroe, but also mass murderers like Saddam Hussein, Osama bin Laden and Adolf Hitler.
A Collection of 17 diaries made and written by Fabiola. The diaries include a report on Fabiola's life and responses to social issues such as the squatters' movement and discrimination.

A pirate radio how-to guide published by Hooligan Press in London in April, 1987. The title comes from a quote from Chantal Paternostre, a Belgian anarchist who said it when arrested on trumped up terrorism charges. She worked for Radio Air Libre, a Brussels pirate radio station.
A collection of 20 colour-corrected photographs of badges, selected at random.

A publication by Bart Hughes 'Trepanation the Cure for Psychosis' published by the Foundation For Independent Thinking in 1970 in Amsterdam. In this publication Bart Hughes summarizes and presents all his studies, experiences and research on trepanation and self-trepanation.

A collection of 105x148 mm cards made out transparent film containing the journal 'Mother Earth'. The content on it has been reduced 25% in size and can be read by a microfiche reader. The journal pays attention to science and literature and was founded by anarchists Emma Goldman and Alexander Berkman. It ran from March 1906 to August 1918.

Audio cassette tapes containing interviews with 28 ex-squatters in Amsterdam, recorded in 1996. The tapes in total last for 19 hours and 31 minutes. The interviews are about the experience of squatting.

A collection of 7 small pennants, connected to the Solidarność (Solidarity) movement, submitted by the Communist Party of the Netherlands. Solidarność is a worker's union that was founded in People's Republic of Poland in the year 1980.
A series of photographs of politicians giving speeches in various occasions and times. The keyword used to collect these photographs in the archive was 'toespraak'.

A Magazine called 'Molo Songololo', starting in 1980, promoting multi-culturalism, non-discrimination and diversity through children’s stories, drawings, poems and articles. The magazine became popular amongst primary school children. Teachers used it in the classroom as an alternative educational tool.
A VHS contained a documentary film titled '총을 들지 않는 사람들' which is made in 2003. The author is Kim Hwantae. The documentary's language is Korean.
A book called 'Mother and Child Care in the USSR' by O.P. Nogina

An audio record called 'Good morning Vietnam' in which the Vietnam war is recorded. Through this record you experience the sound of American soldiers that are in combat as well as civilians grieving over the grave of their loved ones. Good morning Vietnam guides you through the war, like you encounter it yourself.

A collection of sixteen keys scattered across a drawer that was yanked out suddenly from a CNT office in the heated fire of the Spanish Civil War, now confined in the safety of a cardboard box in the IISG, in Amsterdam. It was 1939, Barcelona.

A Board gamemade by Industriebond FNV (Federation of Dutch Trade Unions), specifically aimed at the workers of Philips Telecommunicatie Industrie in Hilversum. FNV is both a labour union and a labour federation. The aim of the game is to encourage workers' participation.
A collection of issues from the magazine 'Practical Self-Sufficiency'.

An urn containing the ashes of Max Nettlau (1865 – 1944). This artefact which should be questioned, might be misinterpreted and misunderstood. It touches on topics of ethics, morality, honor, history, human being and social patterns.
A photograph from 1952, depicting a woman investigating data coming out of ARRA, the oldest computer known in The Netherlands.

Two industrial music VHS tapes called 'Extreme Art 1: Industrial Compilation' published in 1987 and 'Extreme Art 2: Industrial Compilation' published in 1988 by Bizarr Verlag, Germany. The VHS tapes include music videos, live music and art performances from various international, mainly European, artists.

A plastic snow globe with Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels portrayed inside it. The object even in it's purest form already poses a multitude of questions and allows for various interpretations. How can we preserve the feeling of snow when global warming already threatens this phenomenon and how does it affect Marx's image and ideology?
A newspaper called  'Die Rote Fahne' (The Red Flag). I've been researching the Youth Pioneers (Jung Pioniere) in the GDR and this newspaper compliments that research.

A death mask of Herman (Stuuf) Bernard Wiardi Beckman (1904 – 1945). Stuuf was a known Dutch politician and member of the resistance during WWII. In order of his Dutch fellow prisoners the mould of the mask was made after Stuuf's death in a concentration camp in which Stuuf was imprisoned.
A box of children's drawings revolving around the topic of animal rights and animal cruelty. The box belonged to Gerard Esser, a Dutch artist, environmentalist and animal rights activist.

A pornographic magazine from Europe 'Suck'. Created during the 1970s by among others Jim Haynes, William Levy, Heathcote Williams, Germaine Greer, and Jean Shrimpton. The founders of Suck also organised 2 film festivals in Amsterdam titled 'The Wet Dream Film Festival (1 & 2)'. 'Colt und Köcher' is one film screened at these festivals and also the subject of this research.

A briefcase from The Democratic Confederation of Labour (CDT). A national trade union center in Morocco. It was established in 1978. Traditionally, the CDT was allied with the Socialist Union of Popular Forces (USFP), but in 2002 the union broke its ties and subsequently, secretary general Noubir El Amaoui created his own political party.

A journal called 'Der Eigene' which is the first gay journal in the world, published from 1896 to 1932 by Adolf Brand in Berlin. Brand contributed many poems, stories political articles and nude photography.

A publication called 'How to Read Donald Duck' (Para leer al Pato Donald in Spanish) from 1971. This book-length essay by Ariel Dorfman and Armand Mattelart critiques Disney comics from a Marxist point of view as being vehicles for American cultural imperialism. It was first published in Chile.

A magazine called 'Cosmic Paper' from 'De Kosmos Meditation Center' at the Prins Hendrikkade in Amsterdam. The center opened its doors from 1969 to 1992 to thousands of young people in search for enlightenment, self-development and entertainment.

A linocut poster by Semi Ruder from 1984, the Netherlands. It was made during the time when the person identification number was about to be introduced as a centralized human accounting system, and wide protests spread across the country. The poster is one of many opinions against this centralized data collection.

A double album published by PEACE in 1987 called 'F/EAR THIS!'. PEACE is the association of independent Italian alternative labels in support of 'A / Anarchist Magazine'. The project was built by friends, musicians, graphic designers and poets scattered everywhere, both in Italy and abroad. All of them were putting together music, words and images built around a common idea, fear.

A vinyl record, onto which is pressed a violin performance of 'Ciocarlia' by Nicu Stanescu.
